component.name: ChoiceCard
component.description: Present a short set of options as selectable cards to support comparison and deliberate decision-making.

useCases: Selecting a plan or pricing tier
Choosing a configuration mode or template
Picking a payment method or shipping option
Selecting a role or permission level
Any decision where options benefit from description and visual comparison

commonPatterns.name: single-select-radio
commonPatterns.description: Radio-based choice cards for single selection within a group
commonPatterns.composition:
<RadioGroup>
  <ChoiceCard
    htmlFor="plan-starter"
    icon={<Zap className="size-5" />}
    title="Starter"
    description="Best for individuals"
    control={<RadioGroupItem value="starter" id="plan-starter" />}
  />
  <ChoiceCard
    htmlFor="plan-pro"
    icon={<Rocket className="size-5" />}
    title="Pro"
    description="Best for teams"
    control={<RadioGroupItem value="pro" id="plan-pro" />}
  />
</RadioGroup>

commonPatterns.name: multi-select-checkbox
commonPatterns.description: Checkbox-based choice cards for multiple selections
commonPatterns.composition:
<ChoiceCard
  htmlFor="feature-analytics"
  title="Analytics"
  description="Track usage and performance"
  control={<Checkbox id="feature-analytics" />}
/>

commonPatterns.name: control-left
commonPatterns.description: Choice card with the selection control on the left side
commonPatterns.composition:
<ChoiceCard
  htmlFor="option-a"
  controlPosition="left"
  title="Option A"
  description="Description of option A"
  control={<RadioGroupItem value="a" id="option-a" />}
/>

antiPatterns.scenario: Using ChoiceCard for large option sets
antiPatterns.reason: Cards take significant space — large sets become unwieldy and hard to scan
antiPatterns.alternative: Use Select or Combobox for more than 4–5 options

antiPatterns.scenario: Using ChoiceCard for low-stakes incidental selections
antiPatterns.reason: ChoiceCards imply deliberation — trivial toggles should use simpler controls
antiPatterns.alternative: Use a simple Checkbox, Switch, or RadioGroup for quick selections

antiPatterns.reason: Nested card-in-card creates confusing visual depth and interaction targets
antiPatterns.alternative: Place ChoiceCards directly on the page surface or inside a flat container

antiPatterns.scenario: Mixing ChoiceCards with plain radio lists in the same decision set
antiPatterns.reason: Inconsistent selection patterns confuse users about interaction model
antiPatterns.alternative: Use ChoiceCards consistently for all options in a set

semanticMeaning.left: Selection control appears on the left — traditional form layout
semanticMeaning.right: Selection control appears on the right — card-first layout emphasizing content

selectionModel.description: Determined by the control passed to the control prop

slots.icon: Optional icon displayed above the title for visual distinction
slots.title: Primary label for the option (required)
slots.control: The selection control — RadioGroupItem, Checkbox, or Switch

parentConstraints: Single-select ChoiceCards must be wrapped in a RadioGroup
Uses Field, FieldLabel, FieldContent, FieldTitle, and FieldDescription internally for its layout

interactions.click: Clicking anywhere on the card toggles or selects the control
interactions.hover: Card background shifts to accent; text shifts to accent-foreground
interactions.selected: Border changes to primary; 2px primary ring appears; icon and title colors shift to accent-foreground

responsive.mobile: Cards stack vertically at full width
responsive.desktop: Cards can be placed in a grid for side-by-side comparison

accessibility.role: Uses FieldLabel as the card container — the entire card is a label for the control
accessibility.keyboardSupport: Space/Enter to toggle when control is focused; Tab navigates between cards
accessibility.screenReader: Card title and description are announced as part of the control label
accessibility.focusManagement: Focus is on the embedded control (radio, checkbox, switch), not the card itself

rules: Options are presented as visually consistent cards with equal visual weight
The entire card is selectable — it acts as a label for the embedded control
Selection control (radio, switch, checkbox) is always integrated into the card
Use ChoiceCard when comparison and clarity matter more than compactness
Do not mix ChoiceCard with plain radio lists in the same decision set
Avoid nesting ChoiceCards inside other cards

aiHints.context: Use when presenting a small set of options (2–5) that benefit from visual comparison with titles, descriptions, and optional icons. Always wrap single-select ChoiceCards in a RadioGroup. The card uses Field sub-components internally and detects selection via :has([data-state=checked]) CSS.
